awd_titl_txt: Investigations of the Photochemical HONO Formation Reactions of Atmospheric Importance
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is focused on determining the sources of nitrous acid to the atmosphere. Nitrous acid can form hydroxyl radical, an important compound responsible for creating the air pollutant ozone. Nitrous acid can be produced on some environmental surfaces, in the presence of water and nitrogen dioxide. Quantifying the relative importance of the sources of nitrous acid to the atmosphere will improve the understanding of some of the causes of air pollution and climate change.

The objective of this research is to characterize and quantify photochemical sources of nitrous acid (HONO), an important precursor to the hydroxyl radical (OH). The photolysis of HONO significantly influences atmospheric pollutant oxidation and ozone production. Recent laboratory studies have shown that nitrophenols formed from the dark reaction of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) with surface adsorbed polyphenolic compounds and the subsequent photolysis of surface-adsorbed nitrophenols may be a substantial source of HONO. But wavelength-dependent HONO yields, from the photolysis of the adsorbed nitrophenols, have not been characterized.  This work will quantify photochemical HONO and the OH quantum yields from heterogeneous and gas phase photolysis reactions using laser photolysis combined with cavity ring-down spectroscopy and determine the UV/visible absorption cross sections of surface-adsorbed NO3 and nitrophenols as a function of wavelength using Brewster angle cavity ringdown spectroscopy. Additional experiments will provide data on the absorption cross sections of gas phase nitrophenols and HONO yields from nitrate and 2-nitrophenol adsorbed on surfaces that serve as surrogates for various environmentally relevant surfaces.

por.por_cntn:
HONO is an important OH radical precursor in the atmosphere.  HONO photolysis impacts atmospheric pollutant oxidation and ozone production. As measured daytime HONO concentrations significantly exceed predicted values, photolytic sources for HONO have been proposed, including photolysis of nitrate (NO3-) on surfaces and gas phase photolysis of 2-nitrophenols. To determine the magnitude and impact of select gas phase and surface photolysis processes in forming HONO, NOx, and OH, my group quantitatively measured absorption of the near-UV light by molecularly and dissociatively adsorbed HNO3 on sapphire surfaces as a function of the HNO3 pressure by using Brewster angle cavity ring-down spectroscopy. We obtained the apparent monolayer HNO3 absorption cross-sections on sapphire over 290 - 345 nm range. Surface nitrate formation is supported by background transmission changes in the 320 - 345 nm region following exposure of clean sapphire surfaces to many repeated HNO3 deposition/evacuation cycles. We used changes in sapphire window background transmission until nitrate saturated all surface adsorption sites to derive nitrate surface absorption cross-sections. Surface nitrate near-UV spectrum is red-shifted compared to that of aqueous nitrate. Nitrate surface absorption cross-sections over the 325 - 345 nm range are 21 - 826 times larger than those in the liquid phase. We modeled the photolysis rates for surface NO3- and surface HNO3 using laboratory cross-section data. There is reasonable agreement between the reported HNO3/NO3- photolysis rate on urban grime and the modeled surface photolysis rates of HNO3 and NO3-.

We obtained gas phase absorption cross-sections of 2-nitrophenol (2NP), 4-methyl-2-nitrophenol (4M2NP), and 5-methyl-2-nitrophenol (5M2NP) in the 295 - 400 nm region using cavity ring-down spectroscopy. 2-Nitrophenols display broad spectral absorption over this range. Absorption cross-sections of 4M2NP and 5M2NP are of similar size. Their peak cross-sections at 345 nm are larger than that of 2NP. We investigated the HONO, NO2, and OH formation channels following 308 and 351 nm photolysis of 2NP, 4M2NP, and 5M2NP. The OH radical is a direct product from their photolysis with quantum yields from the 308 nm and 351 nm photolysis of about 0.69 and 0.70 for 2NP, about 0.066 and 0.031 for 4M2NP, and about 0.078 and 0.042 for 5M2NP. NO2 did not appear to be a product from photolyzing these 2-nitrophenols. HONO is a direct product from the photolysis of 2NP, 4M2NP, and 5M2NP with quantum yields at 308 and 351 nm of about 0.34 and 0.39 for 2NP, about 0.26 and 0.26 for 4M2NP, and about 0.37 and 0.35 for 5M2NP.  We estimated the 2NP, 4M2NP, and 5M2NP photolysis rate constants using laboratory absorption cross-section and product quantum yield data. We found fast gas phase photolysis of 2-nitrophenol and methyl-2-nitrophenols and significant OH and HONO quantum yields from the photolysis of these compounds. Our findings are highly relevant to the missing OH sources in polluted suburban environments such as Beijing where nitrophenol concentrations up to hundreds of pptv and methyl-nitrophenol concentrations up to 50 pptv have been detected in haze. In a VOC-rich polluted atmosphere such as suburban environments near Beijing and the Pearl River Delta region of China, the measured OH concentrations are significantly higher than predicted values, even after accounting for the contributions of known OH sources. Our results implicated gas phase photolysis of 2NP and M2NPs as important missing OH and missing HONO sources in such environments.

We directly determined the HNO3 coverage on silica surfaces by installing a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) in situ in our surface study chamber. The adsorption behavior of HNO3 on silica surface as a function of the HNO3 pressure observed by Brewster angle cavity ring-down spectroscopy is in excellent agreement with that observed by QCM. We also obtained the NO2 quantum yield from the 308 nm photolysis of HNO3 on fused silica surfaces.

We also conducted a preliminary study to test and confirm the feasibility of determining near-UV extinction cross sections of size-selected sodium nitrate aerosols using cavity ring-down spectroscopy. We have developed the technical capability to study optical properties of aerosols.   

The completed NSF project has broader impacts as well.  The project has directly led to the research training of two postdoctoral scholars and three summer REU students and has broadened the participation of female students. The NSF project allowed us to enhance the research infrastructure of the field, as we developed new, state-of-the-art technique that directly measures absorption by monolayer of adsorbed ions on surfaces. The project facilitated STEM education and educator development through collaboration with a faculty member and a graduate student doing atmospheric chemistry modeling at Howard University. The findings from the NSF project were presented in conferences and published in journals and on institutional website. A quantitative understanding of the atmospheric photochemical sources of HONO and OH will yield information vital to the development of effective pollution prevention and control strategies to protect public health and the environment.
